discussion.title: 8 procs not used
discussion.body:
Dear Miles

I have a dataset of 2000 training points. I have set the number of iterations to 100, procs=8 / cpu.count() and multithreading=True. When I am looking at the CPU usage, I see all 8 of them are at 50-70% during PySr's training. Even if I saturate procs to 32, this issue still remains. What should I change here? 

Although I get the answer in less than 2 minutes even with these settings, I want to make use of all 8 CPUs.

If I run for a higher number of iterations=500 and populations=3*32 over a "pbs" cluster of procs=32, I see the same issue there. Only one CPU is getting used. The settings here were: procs=32, cluster_manager="pbs"

nodes.body:
Does it say the head occupation %? The lower that is, the better. If that number is high, the head worker basically canâ€™t give out work quickly enough. 

To improve this you should increase population size and/or ncyclesperiteration.

Alternatively you can use multiprocessing instead of multithreading by setting `multithreading=False`. I find sometimes that improves usage of cores for whatever reason.

What version of PBS are you using? I know that some people have run into issues on multi-node processing with PBS due to ClusterManagers.jl not yet supporting the latest qsub command line arguments. See https://github.com/JuliaParallel/ClusterManagers.jl/issues/179.

So your current options are to:
1. Use single-node multiprocessing (`cluster_manager=None, multithreading=False, procs=32`).
2. Use a slurm cluster manager, if available, to get working multi-node multiprocessing.
3. Help us fix the issue on https://github.com/JuliaParallel/ClusterManagers.jl/issues/179. It's a bit hard for me to fix this myself since I don't have a PBS cluster I can test it on (all my institutes use slurm). So any help is much appreciated.
@Nakul9621 also this issue is highly relevant! https://github.com/MilesCranmer/PySR/issues/419
